history.content:
Oof 127 + 61C + 170 sounds like a very heavy workload. 127 had weekly homeworks in the spring, which ate up a lot of time. 61C and 170 are of course extremely heavy workloads as well. 

But if you were able to take the heavy duty combo of 61b/70/134 and do well, then you most likely won't have an issue with the sheer amount of work per se. 

However, if the only linear algebra experience under your belt is 16a, I am not sure you would be able to get as much out of the material in 127. You could definitely do well in terms of grades in the course, but from my experience, taking a class that I don't have enough background in means that I learn less of the subtle nuances and connections of the material . 

Here's my recommendation:

Take Math110 + 61C + 170 in the fall, and 127 in the spring. 

Reasons:

-My semester of 110 didn't require us to turn in the homeworks (it was just self practice) which eased some time constraints when I took 110 with 3 other techs. An earlier question on this piazza confirmed that Frenkel has the same policy for this fall

-From my feeling, 127 required a level of understanding of proofs (which I didn't have at the time but you most likely have) and linear algebra that I couldn't have gotten from solely taking Math 54. 

- Taking 110 first helped me first learn more linear algebra, and become deeply familiar with the style of linear algebra proofs, so that I felt prepared for 127. 

- If your goal is to strengthen your linear algebra, there is no better combo to do that than 110+127

- I talked a little more about why 110 + 127 is a good combo in @9910

135+61C+170 would also be doable if you did well in 134. I took 135 with 3 other techs and while it really hurt I survived lol. But if you want to take 127 eventually, and strengthen linear algebra, I'd choose 110 in the fall over 135. 

In terms of how 127 compares to other classes:

-its not really fair to compare it to 70 since 70 is a weeder class and you enter the class knowing very little about math and proofs and such. By the time most people (or at least myself) have taken 127, you've finally achieved the so-called "mathematical maturity" everyone talks about so some parts of it are easier. 

127 is not the hardest class I've taken, but its by far not the easiest. I felt it was just what I would expect from a challenging upper-div.

I'm torn on whether or not to take this class in the fall. I'd be taking this (or whatever I replace it with) in addition to 61c and 170; I took 61b/70/stat 134 last semester and did very well in all 3.

On one hand, I'm interested in learning more about ML, and I want to strengthen my linear algebra. This seems like the most relevant class I could take for that. On the other hand, my only experience with linear algebra is ee16a last fall. I did very well in that class though, and how I handled my spring schedule leads me to believe I could probably do well in 127 if I put in the effort, especially if I start self-studying the last few weeks of the summer.

However, I want to focus on internship recruiting and interview prep in the fall, and I'm not sure if it's a good idea to burden myself with a pretty heavy schedule. I'd replace 127 with either math 110 or stat 135, and I'm pretty confident I could handle 170/61c/{110/135} fairly well (in that it'd be comparable to my spring schedule).

How hard and time consuming is this class compared to something like cs70? I've heard a very very wide range of opinions from "2nd hardest class in EECS" (after 126) to "easier than 70." What was your experience like with the class?

Thanks!
history.subject: Seeking more opinions on eecs 127
